sen.j: 閑院宮（かんいんのみや）は、四世襲親王家の一つで、江戸時代中期に東山天皇の皇子、閑院宮直仁親王が創設した宮家。
sen.e: The Kan in no Miya was one of the four hereditary Imperial family, and it was the princely house which was founded by Emperor Higashiyama's Prince, Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Naohito during middle of the Edo period.

The Kan in no Miya was one of the four hereditary Imperial families, and it was a princely house which was founded by Emperor Higashiyama's Prince, Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Naohito during middle of the Edo period.

The Kan in no Miya was one of the four hereditary Imperial families, and it was a Miyake (house of an imperial prince) which was founded by Emperor Higashiyama's Prince, Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Naohito during middle of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: "princely house"→"Miyake (house of an imperial prince)に変更しました。 "

sen.j: 閑院宮の宮号は平安時代の清和天皇の皇子である貞元親王が閑院を号したことに由来するといわれているが、明確ではない。
sen.e: Although there is no historical proof, it is said the Miya go title of Kanin no Miya came from the occasion Emperor Seiwa's Prince, Imperial Prince Sadamoto named Kan in.
Although there is no historical proof, it is said the Miya go title of Kanin no Miya came from Seiwa's Prince, Imperial Prince Sadamoto, named Kan in.
Although there is no historical proof, it is said the Miya go title of Kanin no Miya came from Heian period Emperor Seiwa's Prince, Imperial Prince Sadamoto, named Kan in.

sen.j: 2代閑院宮直仁親王の王子光格天皇が後桃園天皇の崩御に伴い践祚しているために現在の天皇家は閑院宮系である。
sen.e: Due to the second Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince, Prince Naohito's Prince, Emperor Kokaku's succession to the throne after Emperor Gomomozono died, the current Imperial family has the Kan in no Miya line.

Due to the second Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince, Prince Naohito's Prince, Emperor Kokaku's succession to the throne after the death of Emperor Gomomozono, the current Imperial family has the Kan in no Miya line.

Due to the second Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince, Prince Naohito's Prince, Emperor Kokaku's succession to the throne after the death of Emperor Gomomozono, the current Imperial family has the Kan in no Miya line.

tit.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 当時の皇室では皇位継承予定者以外の親王は世襲親王家を継承する例外を除いては出家して法親王となる事が慣例となっていた。
sen.e: It took granted for the Imperial Princes who would not succeed to the throne were to take over the hereditary Imperial family, or to enter into the priesthood to become the cloister emperor from the Imperial family in those days.
It was taken for granted that an Imperial Prince who would not succeed to the throne would take over the hereditary Imperial family, or enter into the priesthood to become a cloistered emperor.
It was taken for granted that an Imperial Prince who would not succeed to the throne would take over the hereditary Imperial family, or enter into the priesthood to become a cloistered emperor.

sen.j: ところが、承応3年（1654年）後光明天皇が22歳の若さで崩御したときに天皇の近親の皇族男子は殆ど出家していて、その後継問題で紛糾した。
sen.e: However, in 1654, since Emperor Gokomyo died when he was twenty two years old, most of the Imperial male relatives of the Emperor went into the priesthood, the issue who to succeed to the throne became complicated.

However, in 1654, since Emperor Gokomyo died when he was just twenty two years old, most of the Imperial male relatives of the Emperor had gone into the priesthood, so, who would succeed to the throne became a complicated issue.

However, in 1654, since Emperor Gokomyo died when he was just twenty two years old, most of the Imperial male relatives of the Emperor had gone into the priesthood, so, who would succeed to the throne became a complicated issue.

sen.j: 都が平安京に移って以降、いったん出家した皇族が還俗して践祚した例はなく、この時院政を敷いていた後水尾天皇はその第19皇子である高貴宮（後の霊元天皇）を践祚させようとしたが、高貴宮は生後間もなかったので、四世襲親王家の一つである有栖川宮を継承していた良仁親王が高貴宮が成長するまでの間の中継ぎとして践祚して後西天皇となった。
sen.e: There was no other example like this, the Imperial member once entered into the priesthood and returned to secular life to enthrone as an emperor, at this period Emperor Gomizunoo who used to rule the cloister government, tried to let his nineteenth Prince, Ade no Miya (current Emperor Reigen) to succeed to the throne, however the Prince was just born not so long ago, it was decided Imperial Prince Nagahito who succeeded to the Arisugawa no Miya, one of the four hereditary Imperial family, to succeed the throne temporally and named Emperor Gosai until Ade no Miya was old enough to become Emperor.

At the time, there was no precedent where an Imperial member entered priesthood and then returned to a secular life to become enthroned as emperor, Emperor Gomizunoo, who used to rule the cloistered government, tried to have his nineteenth Prince, Ade no Miya (the current Emperor Reigen) succeed the throne, however the Prince had just been born, so, it was decided that Imperial Prince Nagahito who belonged to the Arisugawa no Miya, one of the four hereditary Imperial families, would temporarily succeed the throne and be named Emperor Gosai until Ade no Miya was old enough to become Emperor.

At the time, there was no precedent where an Imperial member entered priesthood and then returned to a secular life to become enthroned as emperor, Emperor Gomizunoo, who used to rule the cloistered government, tried to have his nineteenth Prince, Ade no Miya (the later Emperor Reigen) succeed the throne, however the Prince Ade no Miya had just been born, so, it was decided that Imperial Prince Nagahito who belonged to the Arisugawa no Miya, one of the four hereditary Imperial families, would temporarily succeed the throne and be named Emperor Gosai until Ade no Miya was old enough to become Emperor.
sen.cmt: スペース削除current→laterAde no Miya補足

sen.j: その苦い経験から皇統の断絶を危惧した新井白石が、徳川将軍家に徳川御三家があるように、皇室にもそれを補完する新たな宮家を必要との建言を征夷大将軍徳川家宣に出した。
sen.e: After experiencing above difficult situation, Hakuseki ARAI concerned the discontinuity of the Imperial line and suggested to the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Ienobu TOKUGAWA, saying there was a need to establish subsidiary new princely house to support the Tokugawa Shogun family, since there are three branch families of the Tokugawa House in the Shogun family.

After experiencing such difficulties, Hakuseki ARAI, who was concerned about the discontinuity of the Imperial line, suggested to the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Ienobu TOKUGAWA, that there was a need to establish a new subsidiary prince house to support the Tokugawa Shogun family, since there are three branch families of the Tokugawa House in the Shogun family.
sen.cmt: revised for clarity, I'm not sure about the term used in the translation "prince house" or the translators original "princely house" it does not seem like a correct term? Also, the last part " "since there are three branch families of the Tokugawa House in the Shogun family" it's not clear how this relates to the problem of the "discontinuity of the Imperial line" and what is meant by the "Tokugawa House?"
sen.e: After experiencing such difficulties, Hakuseki ARAI, who was concerned about the discontinuity of the Imperial line, suggested to the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Ienobu TOKUGAWA, that there was a need to establish a new subsidiary Miyake to support the Imperial family, after considering the fact that in the Shogun family, there are three branch families of the Tokugawa House.
sen.cmt: スペース削除ネイティブチェッカーのコメント通り、再翻訳しました。"Miyake (families allowed to have the status of Imperial family)"→"Miyake"に変更しました。

sen.j: 一方、同様の危機感を抱いていた東山天皇も家宣の舅でもある関白近衛基熙を通じて、実子である秀宮（直仁親王）に新宮家を創設させるための財政的な支援を求めてきた。
sen.e: On the other hand Emperor Higashiyama had a similar concern, he asked for financial support to establish new princely house for his own child, Hide no Miya (Imperial Prince Naohito), through the Chancellor Motohiro KONOE, who was Ienobu' father in law.

Emperor Higashiyama had a similar concern, he asked for financial support to establish a new prince house for his own child, Hide no Miya (Imperial Prince Naohito), through the Chancellor Motohiro KONOE, who was Ienobu's father in law.

Emperor Higashiyama had a similar concern, he asked for financial support to establish a new Miyake for his own child, Hide no Miya (Imperial Prince Naohito), through the Chancellor Motohiro KONOE, who was Ienobu's father in law.
sen.cmt: ネイティブチェッカーのコメント通り、再翻訳しました。

sen.j: このため、宝永7年8月11日（1710年9月4日）、直仁親王を初代とする新宮家創設が決定され、8年後に霊元法皇（東山天皇の父、天皇は1709年に崩御）より直仁親王に対して閑院宮の宮号と1000石の所領を下賜された。
sen.e: Due to above, on September 4th, 1710, the new princely house was decided to establish, Imperial Prince Naohito as a founder, eight years later, the Cloister Emperor Reigen (Emperor Higashiyama's father, the Emperor died in 1709) gave Miya go title and the a feudal estate of one thousand koku to the Imperial Prince Naohito.

Due to above, on September 4th, 1710, the new princely house was decided to appoint Imperial Prince Naohito as the founder eight years later, the Cloistered Emperor Reigen (Emperor Higashiyama's father, the Emperor died in 1709) gave the title "Miya go" and the feudal estate of one thousand koku to Imperial Prince Naohito.
sen.cmt: again here is the term "princely house" and the "princely house decided" (is this some type of group?) this term needs to defined or changed for clarification of meaning. Also, (Emperor Higashiyama's father, the Emperor died in 1709) this is a confusing statement and raises the question, "who is the Emperor who died?... "Emperor Higashiyama's father who was the previous Emperor died in 1709? The term "the Emperor" needs to be clarified as to who or which "the Emperor" is being talked about.
sen.e: Due to the above, on September 4, 1710, the new Miyake was decided to appoint Imperial Prince Naohito as the founder, eight years later, the Cloistered Emperor Reigen (Emperor Higashiyama's father, Emperor Higashiyama himself died in 1709) gave the title Miya go and the feudal estate of one thousand koku to Imperial Prince Naohito.
sen.cmt: G列のネイティブチェッカーのコメント通り、再翻訳をお願いいたします。日付表記原文に『』のない"を削除"princely house"→"Miyake"に変更しました。

sen.j: こうして、寛永2年（1625年）の有栖川宮（高松宮）が創設されて以来の新宮家誕生となった。
sen.e: Thus, the new princely house was established, and it was the first time since Arisugawa no Miya (Takamatsu no Miya) was established in 1625.
Thus, the new princely house was established, and it was the first time since Arisugawa no Miya (Takamatsu no Miya) was established in 1625.
sen.cmt: "princely house" again this term needs definition in order to revise this cell
sen.e: Thus, the new Miyake was established, and it was the first time since Arisugawa no Miya (Takamatsu no Miya) was established in 1625.
sen.cmt: ネイティブチェッカーのコメント通り、再翻訳しました。

sen.j: その屋敷地は、京都御苑の南西部に与えられた。
sen.e: The land to built their mansion was given on the south west side of the Kyoto Imperial Garden.
The location of the land given to built their mansion was on the south west side of the Kyoto Imperial Garden.
The location of the land given to built their mansion was on the south west side of the Kyoto Imperial Garden.

sen.j: 旧閑院宮邸は、近年整備され、場所を変えずに江戸時代の遺構を残す唯一の宮家屋敷である。
sen.e: The former Kan in no Miya palace, which was recently maintenance, is the only princely mansion which locates at the same place as it was from the Edo period and remains the old style.

The former Kan in no Miya palace, recently refurbished, is the only palace belonging to a prince still in it's original location as it was during the Edo period and is kept in it's old original style.
sen.cmt: Palace and mansion should not be used together to refer to the same building, it causes confusion. Use one term only to maintain consistency.
sen.e: The former Kan in no Miya palace, recently refurbished, is the only palace (Miyake) belonging to a prince still in its original location as it was during the Edo period and is kept in it's old original style.
sen.cmt: ネイティブチェッカーのコメント通り、再翻訳しました。"palace"→"palace (Miyake)"に変更しました。

sen.j: 霊元法皇が新宮家創設に反対したとする説があるが、法皇の天皇在位中にも新宮家創設を要望して拒否された経緯があり、自分の代には認めず親幕府派の東山天皇の要望によって認めたことへの不満があったとされている。
sen.e: There was a theory the Cloister Emepror Reigen was against establishing new princely house, there was a history that he also did not approve the same when the idea of establishing new princely house was requested while he was the Emperor, he had a frustration that it was approved by Emperor Hitashiyama's request, who was a supporter of the shogunate government, not when he was in power.

There was a theory that the Cloistered Emperor Reigen was against establishing a new palace, and he was not in favor of the palace when it was requested while he was the Emperor, he was frustration that it had been approved at the request of Emperor Hitashiyama, while he was a supporter of the shogunate government and not when he was in power.
sen.cmt: spelling corrected, "princely house" changed to "palace." "while he was the Emperor" is a confusing statement, because from the context so far, I understood that the "princely house" (palace?) was requested while he was a Prince and not when he was an Emperor. It seems consistency is lacking here.
sen.e: There was a theory that the Cloistered Emperor Reigen was against establishing a new Miyake, and he was not in favor of the Miyake when it was requested while he was in power as an Emperor, he was frustrated that it had been approved at the request of Emperor Higashiyama, while he supported the shogunate government and not when he was in power.
sen.cmt: ネイティブチェッカーのコメント通り、再翻訳しました。Hitashiyama→Higashiyama"palace"→"Miyake"に変更しました。

sen.j: 歴代当主
sen.e: The successive family head
The successive family head
The successive family head

sen.j: 第二代閑院宮典仁親王の時に、新井白石の慧眼が実際に役立つこととなった。
sen.e: Hakuseki ARAI's keen insight became handy while the Second Kan in no Miya, Imperial Prince Sukehito was in power.
Hakuseki ARAI's keen insight was helpful while the Second Kan in no Miya, Imperial Prince Sukehito was in power.
sen.cmt: needed to "format cell" in order to "wrap text," "insight became handy?" perhaps "valuable" or "helpful" is more appropriate.
sen.e: Hakuseki ARAI's keen insight was helpful while the Second Kan in no Miya, Imperial Prince Sukehito was in power.
sen.cmt: ネイティブチェッカーのコメント通り、再翻訳しました。

sen.j: 後桃園天皇が崩御し、天皇には崩御の年に誕生した皇女が一人いるだけであった。
sen.e: When Emperor Gomomozino died, he only had a Princess who was born in the year he died.
When Emperor Gomomozino died, he only had a Princess who was born in the year he died.
When Emperor Gomomozono died, he only had a Princess who was born in the year he died.

sen.j: そこで、典仁親王の第六王子の祐宮が光格天皇として即位した。
sen.e: After that Imperial Prince Sukehito's sixth Prince, Sachi no Miya succeeded to the throne as Emperor Kokaku.
After that, Imperial Prince Sukehito's sixth Prince, Sachi no Miya, succeeded to the throne as Emperor Kokaku.
After that, Imperial Prince Sukehito's sixth Prince, Sachi no Miya, succeeded to the throne as Emperor Kokaku.

sen.j: なお、光格天皇の皇后は後桃園天皇の皇女の欣子内親王である。
sen.e: By the way Emperor Kokaku's Empress was Imperial Princess Kinshi (Yoshiko) who was Emperor Gomomozono's princess.
Incidentally, Emperor Kokaku's Empress was Imperial Princess Kinshi (Yoshiko) who was Emperor Gomomozono's princess.
Incidentally, Emperor Kokaku's Empress was Imperial Princess Kinshi (Yoshiko) who was Emperor Gomomozono's princess.

sen.j: 光格天皇は、実父典仁親王に太上天皇の尊号を贈ろうと考えたが、将軍徳川家斉が父一橋治済に大御所の称号を贈ることを嫌った、老中松平定信の反対に遭い、朝幕間は緊張した（尊号一件・尊号事件）。
sen.e: Emperor Kokaku intended to send the respective title, the retired Emperor to his father, Imperial Prince Sukehito, however Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, Senior Conucillor (of the TOKUGAWA Shogunate) was against it, he also did not approve when Shogun, Ienari TOKUGAWA tried to send a respective title, Ogosho (respective title for someone who retired Shogun, especially applies to Ieyasu and Ienari Tokugawa) to his father, Harusada HITOTSUBASHI, it caused the intense situation between the Shoguate government and the Imperial Palace. (The "honorific title" Incident)
sen.cmt: 尊号一件・尊号事件→the "honorific title" Incident[定訳不明]
sen.e: Emperor Kokaku intended to give the title, "retired Emperor" to his father, Imperial Prince Sukehito, however, Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, Senior Conucillor (of the TOKUGAWA Shogunate) was against it, and also, did not give his approval when Shogun, Ienari TOKUGAWA tried to give the title, "Ogosho" (respective title for someone whois a retired Shogun, especially applies to Ieyasu and Ienari Tokugawa) to his father, Harusada HITOTSUBASHI, this caused tension between the Shoguate government and the Imperial Palace. (The "honorific title" Incident)

Emperor Kokaku intended to give the title, "Retired Emperor" to his father, Imperial Prince Sukehito, however, Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, Senior Councillor (of the TOKUGAWA Shogunate) was against it, and also, did not give his approval when Shogun, Ienari TOKUGAWA tried to give the title, Ogosho (respective title for someone who is a retired Shogun, especially applies to Ieyasu and Ienari Tokugawa) to his father, Harusada HITOTSUBASHI, this caused tension between the Shogunate government and the Imperial Palace. (The "honorific title" Incident)
sen.cmt: スペース削除・挿入上皇表記原文に『』のない"を削除スペル

sen.j: ちなみにこの事件で天皇と定信の双方を説得にあたって事態収拾を図った関白鷹司輔平は初代直仁親王の末子で典仁親王の実弟に当たる。
sen.e: By the way, the Chancellor, Sukehira TAKATSUKASA worked to improve the situation by pasuading the both parties during this incident, he was the youngest child of the first Imperial Prince Naohito and also younger brother of Imperial Prince Sukehito.

Consequently, Chancellor Sukehira TAKATSUKASA worked to improve the situation by pasuading both parties during this incident, he was the youngest child of the first Imperial Prince Naohito and also the younger brother of Imperial Prince Sukehito.

Consequently, Chancellor Sukehira TAKATSUKASA worked to improve the situation by persuading both the Emperor and Sadanobu during this incident, he was the youngest child of the first Imperial Prince Naohito and also the younger brother of Imperial Prince Sukehito.

sen.j: 典仁親王は和歌の門弟をとっており、光格朝にはその歌壇に参加する公家が少なくなかった。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Sukehito had a disciple of Waka, there were many court nobles to participate in tanka circles within Emperor Kokaku's Imperial Palace.
Imperial Prince Sukehito had disciples of Waka, and many court nobles participated in tanka circles within Emperor Kokaku's Imperial Palace.
Imperial Prince Sukehito had disciples of Waka (Japanese poem), and many court nobles participated in tanka circles within Emperor Kokaku's Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 門弟の筆頭格が芝山持豊であったが、彼が本居宣長に傾倒していたことは、宣長が少なからぬ公家と交際するようになったことの一因であろう。
sen.e: The first on the list of Emperor's disciples was Mochitoyo SHIBAYAMA, he was a supporter of Norinaga MOTOORI, and Norinaga had relationship with the court nobles due to this background.
The first on the list of the Emperor's disciples was Mochitoyo SHIBAYAMA, he was a supporter of Norinaga MOTOORI, and Norinaga had relationship with the court nobles due to this background.
The first on the list of the Emperor's disciples was Mochitoyo SHIBAYAMA, he was a supporter of Norinaga MOTOORI, and Norinaga had relationship with the court nobles due to this background.

sen.j: 宣長は典仁親王の王子、妙法院宮真仁法親王に命ぜられて歌を献じている。
sen.e: Norinaga was ordered to make some waka poems by Prince Sukehito's Prince, Myohoin no Miya monk-Imperial Prince.
Norinaga was ordered to write some waka poems by Prince Sukehito's Prince, Myohoin no Miya monk-Imperial Prince.
Norinaga was ordered to write some waka poems by Prince Sukehito's Prince, Myohoin no Miya monk-Imperial Prince.

sen.j: 真仁法親王は円山応挙、呉春らを引き立てたことでも知られ、複数の民間歌人とも交際があった。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Masahito was known he supported Okyo MARUYAMA and Goshun, he associated with a various private poets.
Imperial Prince Masahito was known to support Okyo MARUYAMA and Goshun, and he associated with a various private poets.
Imperial Prince Masahito was known to support Okyo MARUYAMA and Goshun, and he associated with a various private poets.

sen.j: 典仁親王の後は、第三代閑院宮美仁親王、第四代閑院宮孝仁親王、第五代閑院宮愛仁親王と続くが、愛仁親王は25歳の若さで薨去。
sen.e: The succession of the family was continued after Prince Sukehito, the third Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Haruhito, the fourth Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Takahito, the fifth Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Naruhito, however the Prince Naruhito died young, when he was twenty five years old.

The succession of the family was continued after Prince Sukehito; the third Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Haruhito, the fourth Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Takahito, the fifth Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Naruhito, however the Prince Naruhito died young, when he was twenty five years old.
sen.cmt: simi-colon added to separate those in succession
sen.e: The succession of the family was continued after Prince Sukehito; the third Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Haruhito, the fourth Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Takahito, the fifth Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Naruhito, however the Prince Naruhito died young, when he was twenty five years old.

sen.j: 後嗣が無かったため、孝仁親王の妃で愛仁親王の生母の鷹司吉子が当主格とされた。
sen.e: Since there was no one to succeed the family, 吉子 TAKATSUKASA, Imerial Prince Takahito's Empress and Imperial Prince Naruhito's birth mother, was decided to become the head of the family.
sen.cmt: 鷹司吉子→Yoshiko?[読み方確認できず] TAKATSUKASA
sen.e: Since there was no one to succeed the family, 吉子 TAKATSUKASA, Imperial Prince Takahito's Empress, (Imperial Prince Naruhito's birth mother), was decided to become the head of the family.
Since there was no one to succeed the family, Yoshiko TAKATSUKASA, Imperial Prince Takahito's Empress, (Imperial Prince Naruhito's birth mother), was decided to become the head of the family.
sen.cmt: 吉子→Yoshiko［正しい読み方が不明です］

sen.j: 明治時代に入り、伏見宮邦家親王の王子である閑院宮載仁親王を迎える。
sen.e: In Meiji period Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Kotohito who was the Prince of Fushimi no Miya Prince Kuniie, joined the family.
In Meiji period Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Kotohito (the Prince of Fushimi no Miya Prince Kuniie), joined the family.
In the Meiji period Kan in no Miya Imperial Prince Kotohito (the Prince of Fushimi no Miya Prince Kuniie), joined the family.
sen.cmt: "Meiji period"→"the Meiji period"に変更しました。

sen.j: 明治5年（1871年）に閑院宮家を継いだ載仁親王は、フランスへ留学。
sen.e: In 1871 Imperial Prince Kotohito who succeeded to Kan in no Miya went to France to study.
In 1871 Imperial Prince Kotohito, who succeeded to Kan in no Miya, went to France to study.
In 1871 Imperial Prince Kotohito, who succeeded to Kan in no Miya, went to France to study.

sen.j: サン・シール陸軍士官学校、騎兵学校、陸軍大学を卒業し帰国。
sen.e: He returned to Japan after graduated from the Saint-Cyr Military Academy, the cavalry school, the Military Staff College.
He returned to Japan after graduating from Saint-Cyr Military Academy, the cavalry school, the Military Staff College.
He returned to Japan after graduating from Saint-Cyr Military Academy, the cavalry school, the Military Staff College.

sen.j: 明治24年（1891年）、三条実美の二女・智恵子と結婚。
sen.e: He married to Sanetomi SANJO's second daughter, Chieko in 1891.
He married Sanetomi SANJO's second daughter, Chieko in 1891.
He married Sanetomi SANJO's second daughter, Chieko in 1891.

sen.j: 参謀本部に勤務の後、騎兵旅団長。
sen.e: After he worked for the General Staff Main Office, he became a brigade of the cavalry division.
After that, he worked for the General Staff Main Office, he became a brigade officer in the cavalry division.
sen.cmt: cell format, word wrap corrected, "brigade" by itself does not refer to the title of "on" person, but a group of people or "divisions" I inserted "officer" after brigade, hopefully this is an accurate position for him.
sen.e: After that, he worked for the General Staff Main Office, he became a brigade officer in the cavalry division.

sen.j: 日露戦争では、満州軍総司令部付きの武官として従軍した。
sen.e: He worked as a military officer to the Manchuriaan headquarters during Japanese-Russo War.
He worked as a military officer assigned to the Manchurian headquarters during the Russo-Japanese War.
sen.cmt: terminology revised, word order before "War" reversed as I believe this is the popular expression seen elsewhere in print
sen.e: He worked as a military officer assigned to the Manchurian headquarters during the Russo-Japanese War.

sen.j: 大正元年（1912年）に陸軍大将となり、大正8年（1919年）には元帥の称号を賜った。
sen.e: He became the Full General in 1912 and received a honor of marshal in 1919.
He became Full General in 1912 and received the honor of marshal in 1919.
sen.cmt: cell format, word wrap corrected, grammar
sen.e: He became Full General in 1912 and received the honor of marshal in 1919.

sen.j: 昭和6年（1931年）から昭和15年（1940年）まで参謀総長を務めた。
sen.e: He worked as an Armed Forces Chief between 1931 and 1940.
He was Chief of the Armed Forces from 1931 to 1940.
sen.cmt: revised word order and terminology for clarity
sen.e: He was Chief of the Armed Forces from 1931 to 1940.

sen.j: 昭和20年（1945年）5月、81歳で薨去。
sen.e: He died in May 1945 when he was eighty one years old.
He died in May 1945 when he was eighty one years old.
He died in May 1945 when he was eighty one years old.

sen.j: 国葬を賜る。
sen.e: The state funeral was held for him.
A state funeral was held for him.
A state funeral was held for him.

sen.j: また、稀に見る美男子であった。
sen.e: He was exceptionally handsome man.
He was an exceptionally handsome man.
He was an exceptionally handsome man.

sen.j: 第七代閑院宮春仁王は、載仁親王の第二王子として、明治35年（1902年）に誕生。
sen.e: The seventh Kan in no Miya Prince Haruhito was born as the second Prince of Imperial Prince Kotohito.
The seventh Kan in no Miya Prince Haruhito was born as the second Prince of Imperial Prince Kotohito.
The seventh Kan in no Miya Prince Haruhito was born as the second Prince of Imperial Prince Kotohito in 1902.

sen.j: 公爵一条実輝の娘・一条直子と結婚。
sen.e: He married to Prince Saneteru ICHIJO's daughter, Naoko ICHIJO.
He married to Prince Saneteru ICHIJO's daughter, Naoko ICHIJO.
He married to Prince Saneteru ICHIJO's daughter, Naoko ICHIJO.

sen.j: その後、陸軍大学校兵学教官などを経て、終戦時は陸軍少将として、戦争継続を主張した。
sen.e: After that he worked as a teacher of military science at the Military Staff College, he also worked as Major General and insisted to continue the War when it was the end of the War.
After that he worked as a teacher of military science at the Military Staff College, he was also Major General and insisted on continuing the War at the end of the War.
sen.cmt: revised, What war? Russo-Japanese War? If so, should be stated for clarity, ie. "at the end of the Russo-Japanese War."
sen.e: After that he taught military science at the Military Staff College and after World War II, as a Major General, he insisted on continuing the war.

sen.j: 戦後の皇籍離脱の論議では、皇室の藩屏が失われるとして反対の論陣を張ったが、昭和22年（1947年）に皇籍離脱。
sen.e: During the discussion about the secession from the Imperial Family, he took a firm stand against it as he thought it would take the protection away from the Family, however he renounced his membership in the Imperial Family in 1947.

During a discussion about seccession from the Imperial Family, he took a firm stand against it, because he thought it would take security away from the Family, however he renounced his membership in the Imperial Family in 1947.

During a discussion about secession from the Imperial Family, he took a firm stand against it, because he thought it would take security away from the Family, however he renounced his membership in the Imperial Family in 1947.

sen.j: 閑院氏を名乗り、純仁（すみひと）と改名した。
sen.e: He named as Kan in family, and renamed as Sumihito.
He was named "Kan" and then later renamed "Sumihito."
He was named Kan in family and then later renamed Sumihito.
sen.cmt: 原文に『』のない"を削除Kan→Kan in family

sen.j: 戦後の新生活は波乱とスキャンダルに満ちたもので、閑院純仁は実業家としては成功を収めたものの、直子とは離婚。
sen.e: His new life after the War was ups and downs with scandals, although he was a successful businessman, he divorced to Naoko.
His new life after the War was up and down with scandal, and although he was a successful businessman, he divorced hia wife Naoko.
His new life after the War was up and down with scandal, and although he was a successful businessman, he divorced his wife Naoko.

sen.j: 妹の華子女王は、皇族出身の元侯爵・華頂博信と結婚したが、恋愛スキャンダルを起こし離婚。
sen.e: His sister, Princess Hanako married to a former Marquis Hironobu KACHO, but divorced to him after having a love affair.
His sister, Princess Hanako married a former Marquis Hironobu KACHO, but divorced him after having an outside love affair.
His sister, Princess Hanako married a former Marquis Hironobu KACHO, who was from the Imperial family, but divorced him after having an outside love affair.
sen.cmt: 「皇族出身の」を訳出しました。

sen.j: 純仁は怒りの余り、兄妹の縁を切るまでに至った。
sen.e: Sumihito was furious about the incident, he disowned Princess Hanako.
Sumihito was furious about the incident, and he disowned Princess Hanako.
Sumihito was furious about the incident, and he disowned Princess Hanako.

sen.j: その後純仁は昭和63年（1988年）6月、85歳で逝去。
sen.e: After that he died in June 1988 when he was eighty five years old.
He died in June 1988 when he was eighty five years old.
He died in June 1988 when he was eighty five years old.

sen.j: 純仁に実子はなく、また養子を取らなかったので閑院家は断絶となる。
sen.e: Since Sumihito did not have any children or adopted children, the Kan in no Miya family died out.
Since Sumihito did not have any children or adopted children, the Kan in no Miya family died out.
Since Sumihito did not have any children or adopted children, the Kan in no Miya family died out.

tit.e: The former Kan in no Miya mansion
The former Kan in no Miya mansion
The former Kan in no Miya mansion

sen.j: 現在も京都市の京都御苑内に、ほぼ完全な形で残る唯一の公家住宅（江戸時代）。
sen.e: This is the only place remains as the completely same style as the court noble's house. (Edo period), and it is currently located within the Kyoto Imperial Garden in Kyoto City.
This is the only place remaining in completely the same style as a court noble's house. (Edo period), and it is currently located within the Kyoto Imperial Garden in Kyoto City.
This is the only place remaining in completely the same style as a court noble's house (Edo period), and it is currently located within the Kyoto Imperial Garden in Kyoto City.

sen.j: 江戸時代の宮家の生活を知ることが出来る貴重な遺構である。
sen.e: This is a rare remain which can tell us how the people of the princely house lived in Edo period.
This is a rare palace, that reveals how royalty lived during the Edo period.
This is a rare palace, that reveals how Miyake lived during the Edo period.

sen.j: 近年整備され、一般に見学することが出来る。
sen.e: The mansion was recently maintenance and is open for the public.
The palace was recently refurbished and is open to the public.
The palace was recently refurbished and is open to the public.

sen.j: ただし、庭園にある池は2/3しか整備されておらず、残りの1/3は地中に眠ったままである。
sen.e: However only two third of the pond in the garden is maintenance, other one third of the pond is still under the ground.
However only two thirds of the pond in the garden was restored, the other one third is still underground.
However only two thirds of the pond in the garden was restored, the other one third is still underground.

sen.j: 識者や市民から、早期の庭園完全復旧の声が非常に高まっている。
sen.e: The learned experts and the residents strongly ask the garden to be fully restored in near future.
Scholars and city residents strongly request that the garden be fully restored in the near future.
Scholars and city residents strongly request that the garden be fully restored in the near future.
